data.title: but what's next and what is his schedule before Paris Olympics
data.meta_description: When is Novak Djokovic playing again after Wimbledon? Is Djokovic playing on clay before the Paris 2024 Olympic Games? Is he playing the Olympics?
data.text:
Novak Djokovic was beaten in a one-sided Wimbledon final by Carlos Alcaraz – but there are still "two big goals" ahead for the 24-time Grand Slam winner this summer.

Djokovic made a remarkable return from knee surgery to make the final at SW19, but he was no match for Alcaraz, who won in straight sets to claim his fourth major.

Djokovic admitted afterwards that he has not been at the level of Alcaraz or world No. 1 Jannik Sinner this year.

However, Djokovic is hoping to return to his best ahead of the Paris 2024 Olympics and the hard-court swing in North America.

Djokovic focused on ‘two big goals’

After being in a race against time to make Wimbledon following knee surgery, now the challenge for Djokovic is switching from grass back to clay.

It’s just three weeks before the tennis event starts at the Paris Olympics on July 27.

The competition will be played at Roland-Garros, the home of the French Open, and there are several clay tournaments taking place beforehand.

Rafael Nadal, who skipped Wimbledon to focus on preparing for the Games, is playing in Bastad this week to get some clay action under his belt.

Djokovic is not currently entered into any events and looks as though he will next be on court at the Olympics representing Serbia.

Speaking after the Wimbledon final, Djokovic said: “I still have intentions to play Olympic Games, hopefully have a chance to fight for a medal for my country. On a completely different surface obviously, going back to the place where I got injured some weeks ago. Let's see.

“Let's see how physically and mentally I'm going to feel. Hopefully I can find the right tennis because I'm going to need all I have and more to go to the final of the Olympic Games.

“The Olympic Games and US Open are the two big goals for the rest of the year for me really. I'm hoping I can be at my best on those two tournaments.”

The US Open, the final major of the year, starts on August 26, three weeks after the conclusion of the tennis event at the Olympics.

If Djokovic goes far in Paris then he might only be able to squeeze in one hard-court event ahead of the US Open – either the Cincinnati Open, which starts on August 12, or Winston-Salem, which starts on August 18.

There is also the Canadian Open, but that starts on August 6, two days after the Olympic tennis final.

Djokovic: I want to keep playing

Even though Djokovic was well beaten in the Wimbledon final there was no indication that he will be following Andy Murray in stepping away from the sport.

The 37-year-old, who is tied with Margaret Court for the most Grand Slam titles in history, said he intends to keep playing.

“As far as coming back here, I mean, I would love to. I don't have anything else in my thoughts right now that this is my last Wimbledon. I really want to play at least whatever…I don't know.

“I don't have any limitations in my mind. I still want to keep going and play as long as I feel like I can play on this high level.”
